Class.@Definition: An object is initialized, read, written, or cleared improperly.

Cause.@Name: Weak Algorithm - including 'Insecure Mode of Operation' - we have it as 'leading to weak algorithm' on the old graph, but is it?
xxx Exposed Key - have to be conseqeunce from IEX failure form a previous Vulnerability

FinalErrorConsequenceType.@Name: xxxSecurity Error - xxx leads to IEX

Consequence.@Name: xxxConfidentiality Error - leads to IEX of Data
xxx~Integrity Error -in some modes of encryption
xxx~Identity Authentication Error -in some modes of encryption

Class.@Definition: Data is signed, source is checked and proved, or data is assured to be unaltered improperly.

Operation.@Name: xxx Verify Signiture - Verify is oeration of DVR; here the operation is specific for _CRY 'Verify Signitire' Verify Signiture

Class.@Definition: Cryptographic keys and other keying material are generated, stored, distributed, used, or destroyed improperly.

Consequence.@Name: Weak Public Key - xxx ENC algorithm - Known Private Key

Definition.#text: Input/Output Check Bugs (incl. Injection Error)
Data Type Bugs (incl. Convert and Compute Errors)">
Memory Bugs (incl. Corruption Errors)
Cryptographic Store or Transfer Bugs
Random Number Generation Bugs
Access Control Bugs
xxx
Data are validated (syntax check) or sanitized (escape, filter, repair) improperly.
Data are verified (semantics check) or corrected (assign value, remove) improperly.
An object, a function, a type, or a namespace is declared or defined improperly.
The name of an object, a function, or a data type is resolved improperly or bound to an improper data type or implementation.
A data value is converted or coerced into another data type improperly.
A numeric, pointer, or string value is calculated improperly of a condition is evaluated improperly.
The pointer to an object is initialized, repositioned, or reassigned to animproper memory address.
An object is allocated, extended, or reallocated (while extending) improperly.
An object is initialized, read, written, or cleared improperly.
An object is deallocated, reduced, or reallocated (while reducing) improperly.
Sensitive data (plaintext) are improperly transformed into unintelligible form (ciphertext) using a cryptographic algorithm and key(s).
Data is signed, source is checked and proved, or data is assured to be unaltered improperly.
Cryptographic keys and other keying material are generated, stored, distributed, used, or destroyed improperly.
A generated output does not satisfy all use-specifictrue-randomness requirements. The output sequence is of random bits, where values are obtained from one or more sources of entropy.
A generated output does not satisfy all use-specificpseudo-randomness requirements. The output sequence is of random bits or numbers from a PRNG.
xxx
xxx
Unauthorized disclosure of information
Unauthorized run of commands or code.
Disruption of access (or use) to information or information system (service).
Explains how the buggy operation is performed.
Explains where the bug is in the operation and in the program.
Explains where the buggy operation code is running.
The (operation, operand1,..., operandn) state tuple has at least one improper element

Lists or rules for checking data syntax and semantics. For example, safelist, denylist, format (e.g., DTD-XML Document Type Definition), and length; or value (incl. NULL or list of values), quantity, range, and type (e.g., a PowerPoint XSD).

Each data type bug or weakness involves one data type related operation. Each of these operations is over an entity: object, function, data type, or namespace. An entity is referred in source code via its declared name.
Primitive, Structured. A data type can be a primitive data type (scalar) or a structured data type (composite).
Numeric, Text, Pointer, Boolean.
Memory region where objects are allocated.
Responsabile for cleaning and deallocating object's memory.
xxx.
xxx.
xxx.
Function, Operator, Method, Lambda Expression, Procedure. Shows which operator or method uses data type(s) improperly.
The Bug is a Coding Error OR xxx rules.
xxx
xxx

xxxThe declaration of an entity may be prefixed by a modifier that enforces required restrictions. For example, access modifiers restrict whether and how a data type, an object, or a function can be used outside its declaration scope.

xxxA scope is a block of code (e.g. { }) where a name is valid, i.e., associated with exactly one entity. Scopes provide the Type System with a context for names lookup, i.e., what namespaces and in which order should be referred to resolve the name.
Has harmed semantics or inconsistent or wrong value or type for its intended use.
xxx need better text - A set of allowed values used with incompatible operations over them.
xxx need better text - An organized block of code that when called takes in data, processes it, and produces an unexpected result(s).
xxx need better text - A piece of memory, with a ill-defined size.
A value that is inconsistent with what it represents, it is out of range for an operation or it has harmed semantics.
A misleading object's address.
The information about an object size is Inaccurate.
xxx
Undefined or exploitable system behavior caused by executing user controlled data. OR Undefined or exploitable system behavior caused by bugs in separating code and data
Undefined or exploitable system behavior caused by memory bugs.
Undefined or exploitable system behavior caused by access control bugs.
Undefined or exploitable system behavior caused by arithmetic operation bugs.
Check data syntax (proper form/grammar) in order to accept (and possibly sanitize) or reject it. Includes checking for missing symbols/elements.
Modify data (neutralize/escape, filter/remove, repair/add symbols) in order to make it valid (well-formed).
Check data semantics (proper value/meaning) in order to accept (and possibly correct) or reject it.
Modify data (assign new value, remove), in order to make it accurate.
The operation is absent.
The operation implementation has a bug.
Accepts bad data.
Rejects good data.
A string of characters (symbols like letter, digit, punctuation) with clearly defined syntax and semantics.
Unintentionally modified data due to a previous weakness (e.g., with a decompress or a decrypt operation) that if not sanitized would end-up as invalid data for next weakness.
Maliciously modified data due to a previous weakness (e.g., with a deserialize, authorize, or crypto verify operation) that would lead to injection error.
Data with harmed syntax due to sanitization errors.
Unintentionally modified policy due to a previous weakness (e.g., with a decompress operation).
Maliciously modified policy due to a previous weakness (e.g., with an authorize operation).
Data with harmed semantics; not accurate value (e.g., outside of a range).
Data value is inconsistent with the value of a related data (e.g., inconstancy between the value of a size variable and the actual buffer size).
Malicious insertion of condition parts (e.g., or 1==1) or entire commands (e.g., drop table) into an input used to construct a database query.
Malicious insertion of new commands into the input to a command that is sent to an operating system (OS) or to a server.
Malicious insertion of new code (incl. with <> elements) into input used as part of an executing application code.
Malicious insertion of data (e.g., with & parameter separator) into input used as parameter/argument in other parts of code.
Malicious insertion of data (e.g., with .. and / or with file entries) into input used to access/modify files or as file content.
The operation is in the programmer's code - in the application itself.
The operation is in a third-party library.
The operation is in the standard library for a particular programming language.
The operation is in the language processor that allows execution or creates executables (compiler, assembler, interpreter).
The bugged code runs in an environment with access control policy with limited (local user) permission.
The bugged code runs in an environment with access control policy with unlimited (admin user) permission.
The bugged code runs in an environment without privilege control. Usually, the program is the only software running and has total access to the hardware.
Data comes from user interface (e.g., text field).
Data comes from permanent storage (e.g., file, database on a storage device).
Data comes from volatile storage (e.g., RAM, cache memory).
Data comes via network (e.g., connecting analog device or another computer).
Policy based on a set of known good content.
Policy based on a set of known bad content; helps reject outright maliciously malformed data.
Policy based on syntax format (e.g., defined via regular expression).
Policy based on allowed number of characters in data. Note that this is not about the data value as size of an object.
Check data for a specific value (incl. NULL or list of values).
Check data for a specific measurable value (e.g., size, time, rate, frequency).
Check data are within a (min, max) interval.
Check data type (e.g., int, float, XSD-XML Schema Definition, or specific structure/object).
Check data against other business logic.
Specify name and type of an object; name, return type, and parameters of a function; or name and type parameters of a type.
Specify data of an object; implementation of a function; or member objects and functions of a type.Refe.
Use a name in local or remote scopes of source code. The Type System resolves the name and binds a data type to it.
Invoke a function implementation. The Type System binds the implementation to the resolved function name. A polymorphic implementation is first resolved and then bound.
Explicitly convert the value of an object to another data type.
Implicitly (forced by the Type System) convert the value of a passed in/out argument or the return into the corresponding parameter or return data type. (Type Coercion is known also as Type Juggling.
Find the result of a numeric, pointer, or string operation.
Find the result of a boolean condition (incl. comparison).
An inappropriate data type is specified; or an inappropriate function/operator is used.
A required behavioral restriction is absent.
A wrong behavioral restriction is specified.
The declaration is in an unnamed scope.
The declaration should be in another scope.
A namespace include is absent; or a scope is not specified in a fully qualified name.
A wrong namespace is included, or a wrong scope is specified in a fully qualified name.
A memory region used to store data.
A numeric, text, pointer/address, or boolean value stored in an object's memory.
A set of allowed values and the operations allowed over them.
An organized block of code that when called takes in data, processes it, and produces a result(s).
Object is resolved from wrong scope, so it's value might be wrong.
Object is resolved from wrong scope,so it's data type might be wrong.
Object's address instead of object's data value.
Inaccurate input data value; i.e., non-verified for harmed semantics.
Data value is smaller than type's lower range.
Data value is larger than type's upper range.
Sign bit is overwritten from type related calculation.
Incorrect value from type conversion or computation.

A moved around-the-clock value over its data type upper or lower range, as it exceeds that range. (Integer Over-/Under-flow is a wrapped-around the upper/lower range integer value; may become very small/large and change to the opposite sign.
Rightmost bits of value that wont fit type size are cut off.
Incorrect value (although fits type size) due to sign flip or signed/unsigned and vice versa conversions.
Real number value precision loss.
Unsigned instead of signed data type is specified or vise versa.
Higher precision data type is needed (e.g. double instead of float).
Specific constructor, method, or overloaded function is missing.
Argument's data type is different from function's parameter data type.
Generic object instantiated via wrong type argument.
Object invoking an overriden function is of wrong subtype data type.
Argument to an overloaded function is of wrong data type.
Function implementation in a particular subclass is absent.
Implementation for particular function parameters' data types is absent.
Data type range or structure is not correct.
Data type is resolved from wrong scope.
Function is resolved from wrong scope.
Implementation for a wrong data type is bound due to wrong generic type arguments.
Implementation from wrong subtype is bound due to a wrong invoking subtype object.
Wrong overloaded implementation is bound due to wrong function arguments.
Unauthorized access to an object exposes sensitive data or allows access to member functions.
Unauthorized access to a data type allows access to member objects and functions.
Unauthorized access to a function.
The Type System cannon represent the computation result (e.g. division by 0).
Mimics the hardware units and is not built from other data types - e.g. int (long, short, signed), float, double, string, boolean.
Builds of other data types; have members of primitive and/or structured data types - e.g. array, record, struct, union, class, interface.
A non-polymorphic entity.
An entity parameterized by type.
Functions with the same name in the same declaration scope, but implemented with different signature.
Functions with the same name as one in the base type, but implemented in different subtypes.
Look up entity name and if needed determine data type (infer from value, through hierarchy, via generic type attribute).
Connect object data type, function return type, parameter data type, or simple function implementation.
Resolve subtype and set generic function implementation.
Resolve overriden function via subtype object and set implementation.
Resolve overloaded function via signature and set implementation.
Supply "in" arguments' data values to a function/ operator.
Supply "out" or "in/out" arguments' data values or a return value to a function/ operator.
A function with a symbolic name that implements a mathematical, relational or logical operation.
A member function of an OOP class.
An anonymous function, implemented within another function.
A function with a void return type.
An organization of entities' names, utilized to avoid names collision.
A number stored in an object's memory.
A string stored in an object's memory.
A holder of the memory address of an object.
A truth value (true or false; 1 or 0), stored in an object's memory.
The first  assign  of  an  object  address  to  a  pointer; positions  the  pointer  at  the  start  of  the  object.
Changes the pointer to another position inside  its  object.
Changes the  pointer  to  a  different  object.
Reserves space in memory for an object; defines its initial boundaries and size.
Allocates additional memory for an object in the same space; redefines its boundaries and size.
Allocates a new larger piece of memory for an object at a new address, copies the object content there, reassigns its pointer, and deallocates the previous piece of memory.
The first write into an object, after it is allocated.
Gets content from an object.
Puts content into an object.
The very last write into an object, before it is deallocated.
Overreaches Initialize, Read, Write, and Clear, focus is on object access, no matter if its for reading or for writing.
Releases the allocated memory of an object.
Deallocates part of the object memory; redefines its boundaries and size.
Allocates a new smaller space in memory for an object at a new address, copies part of the object content there, reassigns the pointer, and deallocates the previous piece of memory.
The deallocation function does not match the allocation function used for the same object.
Points to the zero address, a specific invalid address.
Points to an arbitrary address, because it has not been initialized or an erroneous allocation routine is used.
Still points to the address of its successfully deallocated object.
Points after/over the upper bound for its object.
Points to a miscalculated position inside its object bounds.
Points before/under the lower bound of its object.
The pointer is modified to an improperly checked address.
The pointer points a wrong specific address.
The pointer does not match the type of the object, due to wrong type casting.
The pointer points to an OS protected or non-existing address.
The only pointer of an already allocated object is used to allocate a new object.
The allocated memory is too little for the data it should store.
The value used as size does not match the real size of the object.
More memory requested than available.
An object has no pointer pointing to it.
Attempt to deallocate a deallocated object or via an uninitialized pointer.
Object data is unintentionally altered.
Object data is not filled in before use.
Object data not overwritten before deallocation.
Attempt to access an object for read or write through a NULL pointer.
Attempt to access an object via an altered pointer (not legitimate dereference of tainted pointers).
Pointer and object have different types.
Attempt to use a deallocated object.
Read or write above the object upper bound.
Read or write below the object lower bounds.
An attempt to access an object for read or write via an uninitialized pointer.
The bugged code runs in an environment with privilege levels, but in unprivileged mode (e.g., ring 3 in x86 architecture).
The bugged code runs in an environment with privilege levels with access privileged instructions (e.g., ring 0 in x86 architecture).
The object is a non-static local variable (defined in a function, a passed parameters, or a function return address).
The object is a dynamically allocated data structure (e.g., via malloc() and new).
The operation is performed over a particular object element.
The operation is performed after iterating over the object elements.
The operation is performed without a function call.
The operation is performed by a function/ method) call.
The object has no owner.
The object has one owner.
The object has more than one owner.
A few bytes of memory are accessed.
Several bytes of memory are accessed, but less than 1 KB.
More than 1 KB of memory is accessed.

A coding error that needs to be fixed.
			BF: Caused by an improper operation or rule (e.g. policy, scope, modifier) - the underlying start error of a vulnerability.

Caused by a bug or ill-formed data. A weakness type is also a meaningful notion, as different vulnerabilities may have the same type of underlying weaknesses.
			BF: Caused by an improper operand that is result from the operation of a previous bug/weakness: improper object (address, size), data (type, value), function (signature, implementation), or rule as object (e.g. policy data) - underlying intermediate error of a vulnerability.

An instance of a weakness type that leads to a security failure. It may have more than one underlying weaknesses linked by causality.
			BF: A bug[-weakness(es)]-failure(s) chain formed by consequence-cause transitions.

Undefined or exploitable system behavior.
			BF: A consequence of the last element of a bug[-weakness(es)] vulnerability chain.

A violation of a system security requirement.
			BF: Caused by a final error consequence. Several vulnerability chains might converge at this final error conseqeunce to cause the failure.
It is a taxonomy category of weakness defined by a set of attributes one cause and one consequence.
What make the weakness happen.
The effect of the weakness on the software
